This is a great discussion and I've been enjoying following along.

In the =
(somewhere in the region north of) ten years that I've been using
JUnit, I =
have never had their use mandated *and* enforced by an employer and
I've ne=
ver been asked about them in an interview.

I just applied for a developer =
position at nearby big city and had to
complete a pre-screening call techni=
cal questionnaire and some of the Java
questions included "write a method t=
hat does X", but no mention of JUnit (or
any other such tool). So, I threw =
caution to the wind and submitted not only
methods that did X, but unit tes=
ts to ensure that the method really did do
my best understanding of X.

Two=
 of my three previous employers had zero unit tests in-house when I
stepped=
 through the door. In both of them, I wrote the first tests and
started try=
ing to share the vision of tested code being somewhere that bugs
can't hide=
. It's hard work.

Unit testing should be a "no-brainer", but I find that i=
t's still treated
poorly within corporations.

Simon
